Unnamed: 2: Definitions
Evidence indicates that river channels have moved in the past
Evidence indicates that the coastline has advanced (i.e. moved seaward) in the past
Evidence indicates that the coastline has retreated (i.e. moved landward) in the past
Evidence suggests the geological deposit/feature under consideration has a high (but not certain) likelihood of containing archaeological material
Evidence indicates that the water level of a lake has fluctuated (i.e. risen or fallen) in the past
Evidence suggests the geological deposit/feature under consideration has a low (but not certain) likelihood of containing archaeological material
Evidence indicates that a natural hazard, such as an earthquake, volcano, tsunamic etc…, has occurred sometime in the past

Evidence suggests the geological deposit/feature under consideration preserves organic material. Note that this includes naturally occuring material (e.g. plant remains) as well as organic archaeological artefacts
Evidence indicates that parts of a landscape which existed before the present day, including landforms and sedimentary deposits, are still preserved either on, or buried under, the Earth's surface
Evidence indicates that although archaeological remains may be present, they are likely reworked (resulting in the loss of spatial relationships) and no longer in situ
Evidence indicates that sea-level has fallen in the past
Evidence indicates that sea-level has risen in the past
Evidence indicates that sea-level has has fluctuated (i.e. risen or fallen) in the past
Downward movement of the ground surface due to tectonic processes including both long-term (e.g. plate movement) and short-term (e.g. earthquake)
Upward movement of the ground surface due to tectonic processes including both long-term (e.g. plate movement) and short-term (e.g. earthquake)

مؤشر /أدلة للتغيرات: غير محدد أو لا يمكن تحديده
Unnamed: 2: The archaeological or geoscientific implications of the evidence under consideration is unknown
Definitions

The investigator has some issues of certainty regarding the interpreted significance (process indicators) of the geoarchaeological evidence; e.g. there are clear weakness/limitations in the evidence which mean that alternative explanations are plausible

The investigator has minor issues of certainty regarding the interpreted significance (process indicators) of the geoarchaeological evidence; e.g. the evidence is generally strong with only minor limitations and possibilities for alternative explanations
The investigator is definitely certain of the interpreted significance (process indicators) of the geoarchaeological evidence. The evidence is definitive and no alternative explanations are possible
For use when Unknown has been entered as the Process Indicator
Definitions
12 nautical miles from the coastline (if unsure check https://www.marineregions.org/eezmapper.php)
200 nautical miles from the coastline (if unsure check https://www.marineregions.org/eezmapper.php)
Beyond 200 nautical miles from the coastline (if unsure check https://www.marineregions.org/eezmapper.php)
Maritime region type not applicable as site lies inland
Definitions
The mapped extent of the geoarchaeological evidence reflects the extent of the dataset available (e.g. box showing the extent of available geophysical survey data).

The mapped extent of the geoarchaeological evidence has been interpolated outside the bounds of the available data (e.g. polygon showing the extent of a deposit which is interpolated from scattered individual cores).
The mapped extent of the geoarchaeological evidence reflects the extent of the evidence as observed from available data (e.g. polygon over a series of beach ridges visible on satellite images).
